content.description:
Best trad line in area, has only seen a few ascents. Couldn't find out who did it and what style. We took the liberty to name it. Start in chossy band below nice open book w'2" crack going up to mini roof, turn on left then trend right over stegosaurus flakes, solid and cool. Then ascend straight in finger crack with pods and good small edges for feet.  

  Bolted variation climbs on right face (5.11c). Finish same crack to new chain anchor.
content.protection: Full set of nuts and cams to two inches. Two bolt anchor.
content.location: Far left of cliff in beautiful black rock.  Middle line of black section

content.description: The obvious thin face just right of "Mixed Bag". Very thin crux moves on sharp dime-size edges. The crux is a short dyno off small edges and bad feet.
content.protection: Short line of bolts on slab and then joins Mixed Bag.

content.description:
Extreme palming & stemming will get you past the crux moves. Save something for the upper, pumpy moves. 

  Quality!
content.location: About 100 feet right of the obvious black crack on the left side of the cliff is a V-corner with a thin seam. This is the route.

content.description: This is a cool route with a thin crux down low and a pumpy one on the arete up high.
content.location: First bolted route to the left of the black crack.

content.description: Several short crux sections on great basalt.
content.protection: Mixed thin gear, a gold Camalot and 10 quickdraws.
content.location: First route on the far left side of the wall at a short shallow corner/crack.

content.description: Start in open book with perfect finger crack and some edges to set up for crux bulge throw for slopers over bulge and establish yourself on face for some gear. Go up steep face and crack to anchors on left.  Another route put up in 80's? only one bolt at time of first ascent but added another. A huge flake pulled off by first bolt and a jug broke off at crux while cleaning so it felt ok to claim 1st ascent, but it wasn't us. Probably 5.10+ before.
content.protection: Bolts and gear to 3" to lower off

content.description: Continuous climbing with the crux at the top. Classic!
content.location: The third (bolted) route on the far left side (left to right) of the wall.

content.description: Crux above at orange overhanging face.  Nice rest beforehand with opportunity to admire Frankenstone in-situ.
content.location: Midway between Black Crack and Big Scary Corner

climbs.name: Flying Squirrel
climbs.fa: Tim Naylor (FFA - maybe Aaron Josh, Peter, Rick or Shibli???)

content.description: Starts with face climbing on horizonal rails to a wide, unstemmable corner with bolt-line along right side in unblemished dark rock. Trick moves gain a ledge below the crux headwall, which is very well bolted (thankfully, keeps you off the ledge). Big moves on thinner holds, very fun and sustained, to the top.
content.location: This is the un-named 12- between Penguin and Cat-Woman.

content.description: Start in left facing corner to broken vertical crack (same as Alfred)

climbs.name: Cat Woman
climbs.fa: Bob D'Antonio, Mike Howard & Jay Foley

content.description:
Steep climbing up a shallow corner. Crux is stepping  right to the slab. 

  Sweet & seductive!
content.location: About 20 feet left of the Penguin.

content.description: Climb the wide crack in middle of black streak for about 40'. 1.5" crack in the back for pro and laybacking. Then up broken face and blocks to anchors.  Fun unique climbing on surprisingly solid rock. Sometimes dirty.
content.location: The black section of rock that faces the road and big talus pile.  Mariposa to the right and another short finger crack toprope to the left.

content.description: Off Finger to Hands up to sharp pinned block (Bat deep in crack).  Crux at roof.  Full value. Try to avoid loose blocks above roof to right. Old anchor up high in loose ground.  We were unable to find who placed this or if crack had FA (be glad to change name and report the true FA, please e-mail me with any info).
content.protection: Cams from 00 to #3. May need doubles in small sizes up high or run it out.  One high bolt to keep rope out of sharp crack (potential rope damage).
content.location: About 30 feet to right of Black Crack.

content.description: Power laybacking past the first bolt is the crux.
content.protection: Some thin gear and 10 quickdraws. Rap from two-bolt anchor.
content.location: V-corner with thin finger crack 50 feet right of obvious black crack on the left side of the crag.

content.description:
Frankenstone

  Crack 5.11 variation for #9
